results.title: Seeds of change
results.creator_credit: Diane O'Connor and Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description: Examines changes in Victorian farm life documenting its evolution from horse to tractor to modern machinery. Filmed on location at Jeparit, this program uses period re-creation and documentary footage.

results.title: Seeds of a new life
results.creator_credit: Nigel Evans, Richard Mordaunt, John Bloomfield and Randel Evans Productions
results.brief_description: Shows the work of Dorothy Heathcote, lecturer in drama, and a group of her students with the mentally handicapped children and adults at Earls House Hospital. Dorothy Heathcote discusses and demonstrates her methods and the patients participate in a variety of developmental acting and thinking activities.

results.title: Seeds in the wind
results.creator_credit: Paul Carpita and Triangle Film Productions
results.brief_description:
The boy decides to wag school because of a punishment given to him the previous day. He spends the time wandering around the docks smoking, thinking up excuses for his teacher, watching the loading and unloading of ships, standing, dwarfed in a drydock, hoping to fulfil his ambition to leave school and become apprenticed to one of the people he is watching - the welders, the painters, the carpenters.
En glish adaptation by Peter Graham.

results.title: Seeds and weeds: observing plants
results.creator_credit: Reinald Werrenrath Jr and Goldberg-Werrenrath Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Science fact and fun”

Points out various types of weeds and notes their effective methods of seed dispersal in terms of the particular environments in which they can survive. Introduces the process of germination and the importance of sunlight for growth.

results.title: Seed of success
results.creator_credit: Norman Laird and Tasmanian Government Film Unit
results.brief_description: The Potato Seed Certification Scheme operated by the Tasmanian Department of Agriculture. Plants grown at the Tewksbury Potato Station are continuously tested for infection, and healthy seed is supplied to seed growers whose farms are inspected regularly. The certified seed which they produce carries a tag on the bag which guarantees its freedom from infection. This scheme is responsible for a rise from 2.1/2 to 4 tons per acre in Tasmania’s average yield of potatoes to the acre.

results.title: Seed germination
results.creator_credit: William M. Harlow and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program. Unit 2. Plant life”

Explains how seeds serve plants in reproduction, distribution and as a device to survive unfavourable climatic periods. Shows how research into seed germination aids biologists in understanding growth, development and metabolism.

results.title: Seed dispersal: seed dispersal by burial
results.brief_description: An educational documentary that examines the sowing of seeds, fertilisation and their eventual sprouting. Once sprouting has taken place the seeds are released from the grown plant.

results.title: Seed dispersal. - 3rd ed.
results.creator_credit: John Walker and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Presents a visual report on different types of seedcoats and shows how external agents such as man,the wind, animals and birds help each kind become dispersed. Depending on which season it is, this will influence the dispersal of each type of seed.

results.title: Seed dispersal
results.brief_description: Shows ways by which seeds of various plants are scattered in order to insure the propagation of the species. The methods illustrated include dispersal by the wind, transportation by animals, and forceful propulsion from the seed-case
